big Hz noise spike UTC while the earlier range dips happened during the unattended night shift https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3314162/ Preliminary remarks about ER O4b Most of the above still applies to the second half of the fourth observing run so far The Hz roll mode transients at Livingston have become much rarer since the filter tuning in late November and are now about as rare as the Hz ones from Hanford We still have the Hz floor motion coupling at Hanford at similar glitch rates to O4a The medium frequency ripples Hz at Hanford have become relatively rare again like they were before mid July but aren't entirely gone in spite of the baffle adjustments between HAM and HAM Hz glitches still show up occasionally There are still presumably beam jitter "pirate ship" glitches at Hanford in all the previously reported bands except near Hz around Hz in particular We've had substantial numbers of violin mode glitches fundamental or 2nd harmonic from both Hanford and Livingston on several occasions almost all of these show nothing visible at all Gone for now is the squeezer's audio band diagnostic field ADF at Hanford tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk It is no longer being injected at Hz and if when it reappears it may be reconfigured to a lower frequency https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/329/3290294/ Background noise? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Why I call them "fins"! They are part of the Koi Fish glitch They are artefacts of the data processing arising when a loud short duration glitch with much of its noise near Hz interacts with the filtering that removes the ever present Hz noise from the electricity mains supplies Similarly the "lighthouse" effects arise in other subjects when a short duration glitch has enough noise near Hz where the fundamental violin modes ever present to some extent are filtered out Very loud glitches can acquire such artefacts at a number of other frequencies and will then turn into "anglerfish" https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Thank you ZngabitanT https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Blip at with a tomte at which probably has its own object Also diffraction grating https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396657/ Doesn't look like the typical scattered light even with the quiet band between 20Hz The three loud glitches above that band and below 32Hz remind me of a streamlined fish and the single glitch below that band looks like a flattened 'c' https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396667/ non symmetry koi fish https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396682/ maybe 64Hz fuzzy range loud case https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396767/ Atypical koi fish tail off center at also diffraction grating above about 32Hz https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396891/ 128Hz ripple with 'rain' above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396893/ Another Not No Glitch 41Hz Ground motion coupling Also S S S on 2024 https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396948/ Fuzzy? range drops have a brief gap in the plotted curve corresponding to brief drop outs from Observing caused by squeezer unlocks g today LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep and again UTC LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep It is not yet clear what the causal connection is if any Maybe the squeezer subsystem is just another victim of some common environmental influence or maybe it is coupling noise at medium frequencies into the interferometer There are indications LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep that the suspension of the mirror FC at the far end of the squeezer's meter filter cavity has been moving more than it should during some of the times in question in particular in the Hz band Given the laser light circulating back and forth in the filter cavity this could also explain phase noise at multiples of a 62Hz fundamental Yet more of these glitches have arrived overnight Sun Mon As the incoming day shift tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep operator puts it > SQZ dropouts Hz monster is back noisy night LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep with comment refers to a comment on LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep from Friday noting that the noise in DARM and strain is also witnessed by the squeezer's Resonant Locking Field RLF a laser light sideband that circulates in the squeezer's filter cavity alongside the very faint squeezed light field itself before the latter is injected into the interferometer Any motion of the FC mirror suspension would indeed affect both light fields in similar ways Could the Hanford "fuzzy range" episodes have a similar origin? I a scientist working with the Gravity Spy team and the LIGO Detector Characterization group I wanted to reach out to everyone here on Zooniverse to enlist your help in improving the Gravity Spy machine learning based classifications As all of you are aware there have been a few new glitch classes in this past observing run that are quite different from previous observing runs As such the Gravity Spy team is working to update our machine learning models to include these new classes One class of glitch that is particularly confusing the machine learning model is Scattered Light Looking through the set of glitches classified as Scattered Light LIGO researchers have identified at least three different classes that have been placed in this class by the machine learning model These are Traditional scattered light glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional gold set with the arch structure expected of scattered light Cairn glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav cairn gold set like the pile of rocks https en wikipedia org wiki Cairn that are somewhat similar to traditional scattering but without a clear arch structure Hz glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set that are a single line of noise near Hz We need a large dataset of each glitch class particularly for Cairn and Hz glitches to help retrain the Gravity Spy model on these classes It would be very helpful if users could be on the lookout for these types of glitches to create larger collections the larger the collection of glitches that we can identify from each class the better the Gravity Spy model will be able to learn the difference between these classes If you notice these glitches or already have a related collection please add a link to your collection in this thread! H O4b BNS range on from gwistat https thumbnails zooniverse org 600x panoptes uploads zooniverse org project attached image 951 bae 7e 4fa 857e 2e cffc png tab https panoptes uploads zooniverse org project attached image 951 bae 7e 4fa 857e 2e cffc png So the range started to drop at UTC from Mpc to Mpc by then rose again to Mpc before the lock was lost around The lockloss corresponds to S LHO tab https alog ligo wa caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep attributes it to an earthquake But as far as I can tell the range drop wasn't caused by these glitches Subjects from near the beginning and near the end of the episode have much higher SNRs than those from the middle of the episode The stationary background noise must have been much higher near the middle then The glitches seem to have been merely a byproduct of the automation trying to counteract the real issue by periodically adjusting some parameter more or less in discrete steps or more probably in discrete quick little ramp ups or ramp downs with the sudden beginning and end of each quick ramp coupling into the differential arm length to produce the "doubleclicks" More thoughts to follow below moderators researchers https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3390873/ ? Are we seeing a side effect of SUS PI periodically commanding new phase correction values to the fast phase locked loop that applies sine wave forces in the tens of kHz to the test mass quadrants to counteract the oscillation? If so it doesn't seem to have been very successful maybe the rung up mode wasn't the one that SUS PI thought it had to contend with A different mode resonating at a slightly different frequency might have resulted in a long row of less than helpful phase adjustments The logbook provides a little more context but raises yet more questions The Data Quality Shift summary LHO tab https alog ligo wa caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep for the week around July tantalizingly notes > There is a glitch cluster just before H lost lock due to environmental factors on Thursday and Friday Okay the glitch cluster on Thursday is precisely what we're dealing with here What about Friday 05? PI and were unable to be damped down by the GRD and we eventually lost lock Parametric Instability modes and are two which should be familiar to the SUS PI guardian so on this occasion it should have commanded good phases only these two modes are known to be prone to ringing up so fast that the available forces in the suspension actuators aren't strong enough to rein them in Unchecked these modes could cause a lockloss within half a minute or less Thus surviving them for several minutes already counts as a success of sorts Apropos of another lockloss on comments on LHO tab https alog ligo wa caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep contemplate whether different PI modes were involved on different days But they don't mention the episode The comment trail alludes to an adjustment of the PR mirror suspension on Fri which could have affected the circulating light power in the arms in turn affecting the likelihood of exciting any PIs but this adjustment happened after both the and episodes So we LVK sensitivity curves https gwosc org summary pages detector status cache day G1H1L1V OBSERVING HOFT SPECTRUM png tab https gwosc org detector status day And at the frequencies corresponding to the "yardarms" there'll be vertical spikes sticking out These are what the engineers mean when they talk about spectral lines in the measured gravitational strain data stream Normally they're filtered out completely before our subject images are produced So we don't get to see them in our subjects unless there's either a loud glitch upsetting the filtering or unless something has made them fluctuate in intensity on a timescale shorter than about seconds https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3375093/ Thank you Is there any particular classification other than extremely loud? big Hz noise spike UTC while the earlier range dips happened during the unattended night shift https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3314162/ Preliminary remarks about ER O4b Most of the above still applies to the second half of the fourth observing run so far The Hz roll mode transients at Livingston have become much rarer since the filter tuning in late November and are now about as rare as the Hz ones from Hanford We still have the Hz floor motion coupling at Hanford at similar glitch rates to O4a The medium frequency ripples Hz at Hanford have become relatively rare again like they were before mid July but aren't entirely gone in spite of the baffle adjustments between HAM and HAM Hz glitches still show up occasionally There are still presumably beam jitter "pirate ship" glitches at Hanford in all the previously reported bands except near Hz around Hz in particular We've had substantial numbers of violin mode glitches fundamental or 2nd harmonic from both Hanford and Livingston on several occasions almost all of these show nothing visible at all Gone for now is the squeezer's audio band diagnostic field ADF at Hanford tab projects zooniverse Background noise? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Why I call them "fins"! They are part of the Koi Fish glitch They are artefacts of the data processing arising when a loud short duration glitch with much of its noise near Hz interacts with the filtering that removes the ever present Hz noise from the electricity mains supplies Similarly the "lighthouse" effects arise in other subjects when a short duration glitch has enough noise near Hz where the fundamental violin modes ever present to some extent are filtered out Very loud glitches can acquire such artefacts at a number of other frequencies and will then turn into "anglerfish" https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Thank you ZngabitanT https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Blip at with a tomte at which probably has its own object Also diffraction grating https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396657/ Doesn't look like the typical scattered light even with the quiet band between 20Hz The three loud glitches above that band and below 32Hz remind me of a streamlined fish and the single glitch below that band looks like a flattened 'c' https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396667/ non symmetry koi fish https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396682/ maybe 64Hz fuzzy range loud case https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396767/ Atypical koi fish tail off center at also diffraction grating above about 32Hz https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396891/ 128Hz ripple with 'rain' above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396893/ Another Not No Glitch 41Hz Ground motion coupling Also S S S on 2024 https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396948/ Fuzzy? I a scientist working with the Gravity Spy team and the LIGO Detector Characterization group I wanted to reach out to everyone here on Zooniverse to enlist your help in improving the Gravity Spy machine learning based classifications As all of you are aware there have been a few new glitch classes in this past observing run that are quite different from previous observing runs As such the Gravity Spy team is working to update our machine learning models to include these new classes One class of glitch that is particularly confusing the machine learning model is Scattered Light Looking through the set of glitches classified as Scattered Light LIGO researchers have identified at least three different classes that have been placed in this class by the machine learning model These are Traditional scattered light glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional gold set with the arch structure expected of scattered light Cairn glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav cairn gold set like the pile of rocks https en wikipedia org wiki Cairn that are somewhat similar to traditional scattering but without a clear arch structure Hz glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set that are a single line of noise near Hz We need a large dataset of each glitch class particularly for Cairn and Hz glitches to help retrain the Gravity Spy model on these classes It would be very helpful if users could be on the lookout for these types of glitches to create larger collections the larger the collection of glitches that we can identify from each class the better the Gravity Spy model will be able to learn the difference between these classes If you notice these glitches or already have a related collection please add a link to your collection in this thread!     - 1400 Ripple

    - Chirp

    I want a list of novel things which occur in Talk Dataset 2 realtive to Talk Dataset 1.
    1. Citizen scientists are actively identifying and categorizing new types of glitches based on their unique characteristics. I want to know what new glitch classes are proposed. If Talk data set 2 proposes a new glitch class realtive to Talk data set 1, what is the glitch class? How do they describe this glitch class? Provide at least a bullet point for each proposed new glitch class with at least two sentences describing it.

    2. Citizen scientists sometimes question whether there are problems with existing glitch classes: i.e. those listed. I am interested in whether there are any concerns regarding the glitch classes according to the citizen scientists, and whether or not they persist in both sets of Talk Datasets, or if concerns occur only in Talk Dataset 2. If there are concerns, what problems are they claiming exist with the classifcations? Provide at least a couple of sentences describing each concern raised.

    3. Additionally, citizen scientists wish to deepen their knowledge by exploring and learning classifications and technical aspects of glitches. I am interested in whether there are emerging questions related to the glitch classes, sensors, or gravitational wave science in Talk data set 2 relative to Talk data set 1. Describe each question and the reasoning for the question. Provide at least three sentences describing these emerging questions.

    4. The origins of glitches are usually related to enviornemntal factors near the sensors or errors in measurements of sensors themselves. Citizen scientists often attempt to analytically correlate external conditions with glitch occurrences, providing specific hypothetical origins of glitches suggesting potentially gained knowledge in underlying mechanisms of glitch causes or their appearances in spectograms. If Talk data set 2 has more specific hypotheses about where glitch origins, what are these hypotheses? What is each hypothesis' analytical motivation? Provide at least three sentences describing each hypothesis.

    5. Often citizen scientists will question if issues are specifically related to particular sensors or channels. Are there any emerging questions or thoughts concerning the way particular glitches are connected to sensors or channels in Talk Dataset 2 relative to Talk Dataset 1? If these thoughts or questions exist, what specifically do they describe? Provide at least two sentences for these questions or thoughts.

This classification is proposed to describe a scenario where two near simultaneous blip-like glitches appear, suggesting a group or cluster of glitches that aren\'t dense enough to be considered a typical "Flock." This classification reflects the evolving understanding of how glitches can manifest in less densely packed formations, similar to sparse bird flocks.\n   - **"Fuzzy Range"** is another proposed glitch class mentioned in Talk Dataset 2. It is described as a series of glitches that cause severe drops in sensitivity due to their occupation of middle frequencies, where LIGO sensors are usually most sensitive. The name "Fuzzy Range" was derived from the appearance and effect of these glitches on the data quality, indicating a less defined or "fuzzy" quality in the gravitational wave data.\n   - URLs contributing to the response: [Sparse Flock](https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396146/), [Fuzzy Range](https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3395223/)\n\n2. **Concerns with Existing Glitch Classes:**\n   - In Talk Dataset 2, there is a concern that the machine learning model used in the Gravity Spy project is misclassifying certain types of glitches. Specifically, the "Scattered Light" classification is questioned because it seems to encompass multiple distinct types of glitches that should perhaps be classified separately, such as "Cairn" and "60 Hz glitches."\n   - This misclassification underscores a persistence of concerns regarding the adequacy of existing categories to effectively distinguish between subtly different but technically distinct glitch behaviors. to be aware of when checking for overlaps At the high levels of background noise that existed during the middle of the episode both the energy normalization and the whitening which suppresses stationary noise can vary substantially from one subject to the next resulting in quite noticeable visual differences in the bright yellow artefacts the "fins" of the baby Koi Fish in the lower halves of the images even for subjects triggered a mere half second apart with almost three and a half seconds of overlap It doesn't always vary though sometimes the bright features do agree "on the nose" In order to ascertain overlaps then one needs to look carefully at the small faint details in the random background noise between and Hz Examples In both of the following sets of three bright details big Hz noise spike UTC while the earlier range dips happened during the unattended night shift https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3314162/ Preliminary remarks about ER O4b Most of the above still applies to the second half of the fourth observing run so far The Hz roll mode transients at Livingston have become much rarer since the filter tuning in late November and are now about as rare as the Hz ones from Hanford We still have the Hz floor motion coupling at Hanford at similar glitch rates to O4a The medium frequency ripples Hz at Hanford have become relatively rare again like they were before mid July but aren't entirely gone in spite of the baffle adjustments between HAM and HAM Hz glitches still show up occasionally There are still presumably beam jitter "pirate ship" glitches at Hanford in all the previously reported bands except near Hz around Hz in particular We've had substantial numbers of violin mode glitches fundamental or 2nd harmonic from both Hanford and Livingston on several occasions almost all of these show nothing visible at all Gone for now is the squeezer's audio band diagnostic field ADF at Hanford tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk It is no longer being injected at Hz and if when it reappears it may be reconfigured to a lower frequency https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/329/3290294/ Background noise? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Why I call them "fins"! They are part of the Koi Fish glitch They are artefacts of the data processing arising when a loud short duration glitch with much of its noise near Hz interacts with the filtering that removes the ever present Hz noise from the electricity mains supplies Similarly the "lighthouse" effects arise in other subjects when a short duration glitch has enough noise near Hz where the fundamental violin modes ever present to some extent are filtered out Very loud glitches can acquire such artefacts at a number of other frequencies and will then turn into "anglerfish" https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Thank you ZngabitanT https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Blip at with a tomte at which probably has its own object Also diffraction grating https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396657/ Doesn't look like the typical scattered light even with the quiet band between 20Hz The three loud glitches above that band and below 32Hz remind me of a streamlined fish and the single glitch below that band looks like a flattened 'c' https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396667/ non symmetry koi fish https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396682/ maybe 64Hz fuzzy range loud case https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396767/ Atypical koi fish tail off center at also diffraction grating above about 32Hz https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396891/ 128Hz ripple with 'rain' above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396893/ Another Not No Glitch 41Hz Ground motion coupling Also S S S on 2024 https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396948/ Fuzzy? frame https thumbnails zooniverse org 220x panoptes uploads zooniverse org subject location 644c a 4d bc 275a c png tab With thanks to Nicm for Attentive readers may notice that several of the deeper range drops have a brief gap in the plotted curve corresponding to brief drop outs from Observing caused by squeezer unlocks g today LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep and again UTC LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep It is not yet clear what the causal connection is if any Maybe the squeezer subsystem is just another victim of some common environmental influence or maybe it is coupling noise at medium frequencies into the interferometer There are indications LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep that the suspension of the mirror FC at the far end of the squeezer's meter filter cavity has been moving more than it should during some of the times in question in particular in the Hz band Given the laser light circulating back and forth in the filter cavity this could also explain phase noise at multiples of a 62Hz fundamental Yet more of these glitches have arrived overnight Sun Mon As the incoming day shift tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep operator puts it > SQZ dropouts Hz monster is back noisy night LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep with comment refers to a comment on LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep from Friday noting that the noise in DARM and strain is also witnessed by the squeezer's Resonant Locking Field RLF a laser light sideband that circulates in the squeezer's filter cavity alongside the very faint squeezed light field itself before the latter is injected into the interferometer Any motion of the FC mirror suspension would indeed affect both light fields in similar ways Could the Hanford "fuzzy range" episodes have a similar origin? I a scientist working with the Gravity Spy team and the LIGO Detector Characterization group I wanted to reach out to everyone here on Zooniverse to enlist your help in improving the Gravity Spy machine learning based classifications As all of you are aware there have been a few new glitch classes in this past observing run that are quite different from previous observing runs As such the Gravity Spy team is working to update our machine learning models to include these new classes One class of glitch that is particularly confusing the machine learning model is Scattered Light Looking through the set of glitches classified as Scattered Light LIGO researchers have identified at least three different classes that have been placed in this class by the machine learning model These are Traditional scattered light glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional gold set with the arch structure expected of scattered light Cairn glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav cairn gold set like the pile of rocks https en wikipedia org wiki Cairn that are somewhat similar to traditional scattering but without a clear arch structure Hz glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set that are a single line of noise near Hz We need a large dataset of each glitch class particularly for Cairn and Hz glitches to help retrain the Gravity Spy model on these classes It would be very helpful if users could be on the lookout for these types of glitches to create larger collections the larger the collection of glitches that we can identify from each class the better the Gravity Spy model will be able to learn the difference between these classes If you notice these glitches or already have a related collection please add a link to your collection in this thread! single episode at Hanford on during an unattended night shift between about UTC and a probably unrelated lockloss at UTC The underlying cadence appears to persist throughout most of this interval H O4b BNS range on from gwistat https thumbnails zooniverse org 600x panoptes uploads zooniverse org project attached image 951 bae 7e 4fa 857e 2e cffc png tab https panoptes uploads zooniverse org project attached image 951 bae 7e 4fa 857e 2e cffc png So the range started to drop at UTC from Mpc to Mpc by then rose again to Mpc before the lock was lost around The lockloss corresponds to S LHO tab https alog ligo wa caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep attributes it to an earthquake But as far as I can tell the range drop wasn't caused by these glitches Subjects from near the beginning and near the end of the episode have much higher SNRs than those from the middle of the episode The stationary background noise must have been much higher near the middle then The glitches seem to have been merely a byproduct of the automation trying to counteract the real issue by periodically adjusting some parameter more or less in discrete steps or more probably in discrete quick little ramp ups or ramp downs with the sudden beginning and end of each quick ramp coupling into the differential arm length to produce the "doubleclicks" More thoughts to follow below moderators researchers https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3390873/ ? Are we seeing a side effect of SUS PI periodically commanding new phase correction values to the fast phase locked loop that applies sine wave forces in the tens of kHz to the test mass quadrants to counteract the oscillation? If so it doesn't seem to have been very successful maybe the rung up mode wasn't the one that SUS PI thought it had to contend with A different mode resonating at a slightly different frequency might have resulted in a long row of less than helpful phase adjustments The logbook provides a little more context but raises yet more questions The Data Quality Shift summary LHO tab https alog ligo wa caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep for the week around July tantalizingly notes > There is a glitch cluster just before H lost lock due to environmental factors on Thursday and Friday Okay the glitch cluster on Thursday is precisely what we're dealing with here What about Friday 05? PI and were unable to be damped down by the GRD and we eventually lost lock Parametric Instability modes and are two which should be familiar to the SUS PI guardian so on this occasion it should have commanded good phases only these two modes are known to be prone to ringing up so fast that the available forces in the suspension actuators aren't strong enough to rein them in Unchecked these modes could cause a lockloss within half a minute or less Thus surviving them for several minutes already counts as a success of sorts Apropos of another lockloss on comments on LHO tab https alog ligo wa caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep contemplate whether different PI modes were involved on different days But they don't mention the episode The comment trail alludes to an adjustment of the PR mirror suspension on Fri which could have affected the circulating light power in the arms in turn affecting the likelihood of exciting any PIs but this adjustment happened after both the and episodes So we don't have a coherent picture of the whole affair yet The range drop on looks similar to the one on The latter was associated with a rung up PI oscillation near kHz There's no clear statement about LVK sensitivity curves https gwosc org summary pages detector status cache day G1H1L1V OBSERVING HOFT SPECTRUM png tab https gwosc org detector status day And at the frequencies corresponding to the "yardarms" there'll be vertical spikes sticking out These are what the engineers mean when they talk about spectral lines in the measured gravitational strain data stream Normally they're filtered out completely before our subject images are produced So we don't get to see them in our subjects unless there's either a loud glitch upsetting the filtering or unless something has made them fluctuate in intensity on a timescale shorter than about seconds https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3375093/ Thank you Is there any particular classification other than extremely loud? O4b Most of the above still applies to the second half of the fourth observing run so far The Hz roll mode transients at Livingston have become much rarer since the filter tuning in late November and are now about as rare as the Hz ones from Hanford We still have the Hz floor motion coupling at Hanford at similar glitch rates to O4a The medium frequency ripples Hz at Hanford have become relatively rare again like they were before mid July but aren't entirely gone in spite of the baffle adjustments between HAM and HAM Hz glitches still show up occasionally There are still presumably beam jitter "pirate ship" glitches at Hanford in all the previously reported bands except near Hz around Hz in particular We've had substantial numbers of violin mode glitches fundamental or 2nd harmonic from both Hanford and Livingston on several occasions almost all of these show nothing visible at all Gone for now is the squeezer's audio band diagnostic field ADF at Hanford tab projects zooniverse Background noise? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Why I call them "fins"! They are part of the Koi Fish glitch They are artefacts of the data processing arising when a loud short duration glitch with much of its noise near Hz interacts with the filtering that removes the ever present Hz noise from the electricity mains supplies Similarly the "lighthouse" effects arise in other subjects when a short duration glitch has enough noise near Hz where the fundamental violin modes ever present to some extent are filtered out Very loud glitches can acquire such artefacts at a number of other frequencies and will then turn into "anglerfish" https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Thank you ZngabitanT https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Blip at with a tomte at which probably has its own object Also diffraction grating https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396657/ Doesn't look like the typical scattered light even with the quiet band between 20Hz The three loud glitches above that band and below 32Hz remind me of a streamlined fish and the single glitch below that band looks like a flattened 'c' https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396667/ non symmetry koi fish https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396682/ maybe 64Hz fuzzy range loud case https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396767/ Atypical koi fish tail off center at also diffraction grating above about 32Hz https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396891/ 128Hz ripple with 'rain' above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396893/ Another Not No Glitch 41Hz Ground motion coupling Also S S S on 2024 https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396948/ Fuzzy? I a scientist working with the Gravity Spy team and the LIGO Detector Characterization group I wanted to reach out to everyone here on Zooniverse to enlist your help in improving the Gravity Spy machine learning based classifications As all of you are aware there have been a few new glitch classes in this past observing run that are quite different from previous observing runs As such the Gravity Spy team is working to update our machine learning models to include these new classes One class of glitch that is particularly confusing the machine learning model is Scattered Light Looking through the set of glitches classified as Scattered Light LIGO researchers have identified at least three different classes that have been placed in this class by the machine learning model These are Traditional scattered light glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional gold set with the arch structure expected of scattered light Cairn glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav cairn gold set like the pile of rocks https en wikipedia org wiki Cairn that are somewhat similar to traditional scattering but without a clear arch structure Hz glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set that are a single line of noise near Hz We need a large dataset of each glitch class particularly for Cairn and Hz glitches to help retrain the Gravity Spy model on these classes It would be very helpful if users could be on the lookout for these types of glitches to create larger collections the larger the collection of glitches that we can identify from each class the better the Gravity Spy model will be able to learn the difference between these classes If you notice these glitches or already have a related collection please add a link to your collection in this thread!     Also, importantly, we already know about several glitch classes. So if you see these, they are not new:
    - 1080 Line 
    - 1400 Ripple 
    - 70 Hz Line 
    - Air Compressor (50 Hz)
    - Blip 
    - Chirp 
    - Crown 
    - Extremely Loud 
    - Helix 
    - Koi Fish 
    - Low-Frequency Line 
    - No Glitch 
    - Paired Doves 
    - Pizzicato

    - Scattered Light 
    - Scratchy 
    - Tomte

    I want a list of novel things which occur in Talk Dataset 2 realtive to Talk Dataset 1.
    1. Citizen scientists are actively identifying and categorizing new types of glitches based on their unique characteristics. I want to know what new glitch classes are proposed. If Talk data set 2 proposes a new glitch class realtive to Talk data set 1, what is the glitch class? How do they describe this glitch class? Provide at least a bullet point for each proposed new glitch class with at least two sentences describing it.

    2. Citizen scientists sometimes question whether there are problems with existing glitch classes: i.e. those listed. I am interested in whether there are any concerns regarding the glitch classes according to the citizen scientists, and whether or not they persist in both sets of Talk Datasets, or if concerns occur only in Talk Dataset 2. If there are concerns, what problems are they claiming exist with the classifcations? Provide at least a couple of sentences describing each concern raised.

    3. Additionally, citizen scientists wish to deepen their knowledge by exploring and learning classifications and technical aspects of glitches. I am interested in whether there are emerging questions related to the glitch classes, sensors, or gravitational wave science in Talk data set 2 relative to Talk data set 1. Describe each question and the reasoning for the question. Provide at least three sentences describing these emerging questions.

    4. The origins of glitches are usually related to enviornemntal factors near the sensors or errors in measurements of sensors themselves. Citizen scientists often attempt to analytically correlate external conditions with glitch occurrences, providing specific hypothetical origins of glitches suggesting potentially gained knowledge in underlying mechanisms of glitch causes or their appearances in spectograms. If Talk data set 2 has more specific hypotheses about where glitch origins, what are these hypotheses? What is each hypothesis' analytical motivation? Provide at least three sentences describing each hypothesis.

    5. Often citizen scientists will question if issues are specifically related to particular sensors or channels. Are there any emerging questions or thoughts concerning the way particular glitches are connected to sensors or channels in Talk Dataset 2 relative to Talk Dataset 1? If these thoughts or questions exist, what specifically do they describe? Provide at least two sentences for these questions or thoughts.

These glitches are not loud individually but occupy the middle frequencies where LIGO is most sensitive. They were first observed in late November and April at Hanford and have similar occurrences at Livingston, indicating a possibly common underlying cause across sites. Specifically, they are mentioned in relation to severe drops in sensitivity and are linked with subjects from both Hanford and Livingston.\n     - URLs: https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3395223, https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396146\n\n2. **Concerns with Existing Glitch Classes**:\n   - **Scattered Light Misclassifications:** In Talk Dataset 2, there is significant mention of the machine learning model\'s failure to accurately classify different types of scattered light glitches. Although these glitches have been recognized before, Citizen scientists and researchers identify a need for better differentiation among traditional scattered light, Cairn glitches, and 50 Hz glitches. It is evident that the model currently groups diverse glitch phenomena under a broad category, which could hinder precise analysis.\n     - URLs: https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3399349 \n\n3. **Emerging Questions on Classifications and Technical Aspects**:\n   - **Reevaluation of "Fuzzy Range" Phenomenon:** Participants inquire about the nature of "fuzzy range" episodes, questioning whether similar mechanisms might be at play in both Hanford and Livingston setups. This shows a deeper dive into understanding whether shared environmental factors or instrument characteristics are influencing these observations.\n   - **Inquiries about Machine Learning Classifications:** There is a growing need for updating machine learning classifiers as new glitch types are identified. Questions about integrating new data for model training signify an active engagement in enhancing detection algorithms.\n   - **Subdivision of Scattered Light Class:** Questions arise about the appropriate categorization of glitches within the scattered light classification, indicating a push towards more granular understanding and categorization in machine learning models.\n     - URLs: https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3395223, https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3399349 \n\n4. **Hypotheses on Glitch Origins**:\n   - **Environmental Influences on "Fuzzy Range" Glitches:** There are specific hypotheses that these glitches may be influenced by common environmental conditions at both Hanford and Livingston or by shared instrumental characteristics. This hypothesis arises from the observation that similar glitch patterns appear concurrently at different sites.\n   - **Relation of Glitches to External Environmental Factors:** Some glitches are speculated to be caused by external factors like earthquakes or heavy machinery, as indicated by the timing of glitches and external events like earthquakes reported near LIGO sites.\n     - URLs: https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3395223, https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396146\n\n5. **Sensor-Specific Questions and Thoughts in Talk Dataset 2**:\n   - **Inquiries about Specific Sensors\' Roles:** There are discussions about whether particular sensors or subsystems, like the squeezer subsystem, might be contributing to observed glitches, especially in the context of "fuzzy range" episodes. to be aware of when checking for overlaps At the high levels of background noise that existed during the middle of the episode both the energy normalization and the whitening which suppresses stationary noise can vary substantially from one subject to the next resulting in quite noticeable visual differences in the bright yellow artefacts the "fins" of the baby Koi Fish in the lower halves of the images even for subjects triggered a mere half second apart with almost three and a half seconds of overlap It doesn't always vary though sometimes the bright features do agree "on the nose" In order to ascertain overlaps then one needs to look carefully at the small faint details in the random background noise between and Hz Examples In both of the following sets of three bright details big Hz noise spike UTC while the earlier range dips happened during the unattended night shift https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3314162/ Preliminary remarks about ER O4b Most of the above still applies to the second half of the fourth observing run so far The Hz roll mode transients at Livingston have become much rarer since the filter tuning in late November and are now about as rare as the Hz ones from Hanford We still have the Hz floor motion coupling at Hanford at similar glitch rates to O4a The medium frequency ripples Hz at Hanford have become relatively rare again like they were before mid July but aren't entirely gone in spite of the baffle adjustments between HAM and HAM Hz glitches still show up occasionally There are still presumably beam jitter "pirate ship" glitches at Hanford in all the previously reported bands except near Hz around Hz in particular We've had substantial numbers of violin mode glitches fundamental or 2nd harmonic from both Hanford and Livingston on several occasions almost all of these show nothing visible at all Gone for now is the squeezer's audio band diagnostic field ADF at Hanford tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk It is no longer being injected at Hz and if when it reappears it may be reconfigured to a lower frequency https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/329/3290294/ Background noise? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Why I call them "fins"! They are part of the Koi Fish glitch They are artefacts of the data processing arising when a loud short duration glitch with much of its noise near Hz interacts with the filtering that removes the ever present Hz noise from the electricity mains supplies Similarly the "lighthouse" effects arise in other subjects when a short duration glitch has enough noise near Hz where the fundamental violin modes ever present to some extent are filtered out Very loud glitches can acquire such artefacts at a number of other frequencies and will then turn into "anglerfish" https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Thank you ZngabitanT https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Blip at with a tomte at which probably has its own object Also diffraction grating https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396657/ Doesn't look like the typical scattered light even with the quiet band between 20Hz The three loud glitches above that band and below 32Hz remind me of a streamlined fish and the single glitch below that band looks like a flattened 'c' https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396667/ non symmetry koi fish https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396682/ maybe 64Hz fuzzy range loud case https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396767/ Atypical koi fish tail off center at also diffraction grating above about 32Hz https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396891/ 128Hz ripple with 'rain' above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396893/ Another Not No Glitch 41Hz Ground motion coupling Also S S S on 2024 https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396948/ Fuzzy? frame https thumbnails zooniverse org 220x panoptes uploads zooniverse org subject location 644c a 4d bc 275a c png tab With thanks to Nicm for Attentive readers may notice that several of the deeper range drops have a brief gap in the plotted curve corresponding to brief drop outs from Observing caused by squeezer unlocks g today LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep and again UTC LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep It is not yet clear what the causal connection is if any Maybe the squeezer subsystem is just another victim of some common environmental influence or maybe it is coupling noise at medium frequencies into the interferometer There are indications LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep that the suspension of the mirror FC at the far end of the squeezer's meter filter cavity has been moving more than it should during some of the times in question in particular in the Hz band Given the laser light circulating back and forth in the filter cavity this could also explain phase noise at multiples of a 62Hz fundamental Yet more of these glitches have arrived overnight Sun Mon As the incoming day shift tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep operator puts it > SQZ dropouts Hz monster is back noisy night LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep with comment refers to a comment on LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep from Friday noting that the noise in DARM and strain is also witnessed by the squeezer's Resonant Locking Field RLF a laser light sideband that circulates in the squeezer's filter cavity alongside the very faint squeezed light field itself before the latter is injected into the interferometer Any motion of the FC mirror suspension would indeed affect both light fields in similar ways Could the Hanford "fuzzy range" episodes have a similar origin? I a scientist working with the Gravity Spy team and the LIGO Detector Characterization group I wanted to reach out to everyone here on Zooniverse to enlist your help in improving the Gravity Spy machine learning based classifications As all of you are aware there have been a few new glitch classes in this past observing run that are quite different from previous observing runs As such the Gravity Spy team is working to update our machine learning models to include these new classes One class of glitch that is particularly confusing the machine learning model is Scattered Light Looking through the set of glitches classified as Scattered Light LIGO researchers have identified at least three different classes that have been placed in this class by the machine learning model These are Traditional scattered light glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional gold set with the arch structure expected of scattered light Cairn glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav cairn gold set like the pile of rocks https en wikipedia org wiki Cairn that are somewhat similar to traditional scattering but without a clear arch structure Hz glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set that are a single line of noise near Hz We need a large dataset of each glitch class particularly for Cairn and Hz glitches to help retrain the Gravity Spy model on these classes It would be very helpful if users could be on the lookout for these types of glitches to create larger collections the larger the collection of glitches that we can identify from each class the better the Gravity Spy model will be able to learn the difference between these classes If you notice these glitches or already have a related collection please add a link to your collection in this thread! PI and were unable to be damped down by the GRD and we eventually lost lock Parametric Instability modes and are two which should be familiar to the SUS PI guardian so on this occasion it should have commanded good phases only these two modes are known to be prone to ringing up so fast that the available forces in the suspension actuators aren't strong enough to rein them in Unchecked these modes could cause a lockloss within half a minute or less Thus surviving them for several minutes already counts as a success of sorts Apropos of another lockloss on comments on LHO tab https alog ligo wa caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep contemplate whether different PI modes were involved on different days But they don't mention the episode The comment trail alludes to an adjustment of the PR mirror suspension on Fri which could have affected the circulating light power in the arms in turn affecting the likelihood of exciting any PIs but this adjustment happened after both the and episodes So we don't have a coherent picture of the whole affair yet The range drop on looks similar to the one on The latter was associated with a rung up PI oscillation near kHz There's no clear statement about whether that was also the case during the former We have a long row of almost glitch subjects during the former we haven't yet seen any glitches that may have happened during the latter and if they LVK sensitivity curves https gwosc org summary pages detector status cache day G1H1L1V OBSERVING HOFT SPECTRUM png tab https gwosc org detector status day And at the frequencies corresponding to the "yardarms" there'll be vertical spikes sticking out These are what the engineers mean when they talk about spectral lines in the measured gravitational strain data stream Normally they're filtered out completely before our subject images are produced So we don't get to see them in our subjects unless there's either a loud glitch upsetting the filtering or unless something has made them fluctuate in intensity on a timescale shorter than about seconds https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3375093/ Thank you Is there any particular classification other than extremely loud? to be aware of when checking for overlaps At the high levels of background noise that existed during the middle of the episode both the energy normalization and the whitening which suppresses stationary noise can vary substantially from one subject to the next resulting in quite noticeable visual differences in the bright yellow artefacts the "fins" of the baby Koi Fish in the lower halves of the images even for subjects triggered a mere half second apart with almost three and a half seconds of overlap It doesn't always vary though sometimes the bright features do agree "on the nose" In order to ascertain overlaps then one needs to look carefully at the small faint details in the random background noise between and Hz Examples In both of the following sets of three bright details big Hz noise spike UTC while the earlier range dips happened during the unattended night shift https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/762/3314162/ Preliminary remarks about ER O4b Most of the above still applies to the second half of the fourth observing run so far The Hz roll mode transients at Livingston have become much rarer since the filter tuning in late November and are now about as rare as the Hz ones from Hanford We still have the Hz floor motion coupling at Hanford at similar glitch rates to O4a The medium frequency ripples Hz at Hanford have become relatively rare again like they were before mid July but aren't entirely gone in spite of the baffle adjustments between HAM and HAM Hz glitches still show up occasionally There are still presumably beam jitter "pirate ship" glitches at Hanford in all the previously reported bands except near Hz around Hz in particular We've had substantial numbers of violin mode glitches fundamental or 2nd harmonic from both Hanford and Livingston on several occasions almost all of these show nothing visible at all Gone for now is the squeezer's audio band diagnostic field ADF at Hanford tab projects zooniverse Background noise? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Why I call them "fins"! They are part of the Koi Fish glitch They are artefacts of the data processing arising when a loud short duration glitch with much of its noise near Hz interacts with the filtering that removes the ever present Hz noise from the electricity mains supplies Similarly the "lighthouse" effects arise in other subjects when a short duration glitch has enough noise near Hz where the fundamental violin modes ever present to some extent are filtered out Very loud glitches can acquire such artefacts at a number of other frequencies and will then turn into "anglerfish" https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Thank you ZngabitanT https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Blip at with a tomte at which probably has its own object Also diffraction grating https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396657/ Doesn't look like the typical scattered light even with the quiet band between 20Hz The three loud glitches above that band and below 32Hz remind me of a streamlined fish and the single glitch below that band looks like a flattened 'c' https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396667/ non symmetry koi fish https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396682/ maybe 64Hz fuzzy range loud case https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396767/ Atypical koi fish tail off center at also diffraction grating above about 32Hz https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396891/ 128Hz ripple with 'rain' above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396893/ Another Not No Glitch 41Hz Ground motion coupling Also S S S on 2024 https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396948/ Fuzzy? range drops have a brief gap in the plotted curve corresponding to brief drop outs from Observing caused by squeezer unlocks g today LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep and again UTC LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep It is not yet clear what the causal connection is if any Maybe the squeezer subsystem is just another victim of some common environmental influence or maybe it is coupling noise at medium frequencies into the interferometer There are indications LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep that the suspension of the mirror FC at the far end of the squeezer's meter filter cavity has been moving more than it should during some of the times in question in particular in the Hz band Given the laser light circulating back and forth in the filter cavity this could also explain phase noise at multiples of a 62Hz fundamental Yet more of these glitches have arrived overnight Sun Mon As the incoming day shift tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep operator puts it > SQZ dropouts Hz monster is back noisy night LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep with comment refers to a comment on LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep from Friday noting that the noise in DARM and strain is also witnessed by the squeezer's Resonant Locking Field RLF a laser light sideband that circulates in the squeezer's filter cavity alongside the very faint squeezed light field itself before the latter is injected into the interferometer Any motion of the FC mirror suspension would indeed affect both light fields in similar ways Could the Hanford "fuzzy range" episodes have a similar origin? Let's hope it'll succumb to some serious troubleshooting soon even though that'll deprive us of one prolific source of subjects https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3399055/ Hi all! I a scientist working with the Gravity Spy team and the LIGO Detector Characterization group I wanted to reach out to everyone here on Zooniverse to enlist your help in improving the Gravity Spy machine learning based classifications As all of you are aware there have been a few new glitch classes in this past observing run that are quite different from previous observing runs As such the Gravity Spy team is working to update our machine learning models to include these new classes One class of glitch that is particularly confusing the machine learning model is Scattered Light Looking through the set of glitches classified as Scattered Light LIGO researchers have identified at least three different classes that have been placed in this class by the machine learning model These are Traditional scattered light glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional scattering gold set with the arch structure expected of scattered light Cairn glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav cairn gold set like the pile of rocks https en wikipedia org wiki Cairn that are somewhat similar to traditional scattering but without a clear arch structure Hz glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set that are a single line of noise near Hz We need a large dataset of each glitch class particularly for Cairn and Hz glitches to help retrain the Gravity Spy model on these classes It would be very helpful if users could be on the lookout for these types of glitches to create larger collections the larger the collection of glitches that we can identify from each class the better the Gravity Spy model will be able to learn the difference between these classes If you notice these glitches or already have a related collection please add a link to your collection in this thread!     4. The origins of glitches are usually related to enviornemntal factors near the sensors or errors in measurements of sensors themselves. Provide at least three sentences describing each hypothesis.

LVK sensitivity curves https gwosc org summary pages detector status cache day G1H1L1V OBSERVING HOFT SPECTRUM png tab https gwosc org detector status day And at the frequencies corresponding to the "yardarms" there'll be vertical spikes sticking out These are what the engineers mean when they talk about spectral lines in the measured gravitational strain data stream Normally they're filtered out completely before our subject images are produced So we don't get to see them in our subjects unless there's either a loud glitch upsetting the filtering or unless something has made them fluctuate in intensity on a timescale shorter than about seconds https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3375093/ Thank you Is there any particular classification other than extremely loud? to be aware of when checking for overlaps At the high levels of background noise that existed during the middle of the episode both the energy normalization and the whitening which suppresses stationary noise can vary substantially from one subject to the next resulting in quite noticeable visual differences in the bright yellow artefacts the "fins" of the baby Koi Fish in the lower halves of the images even for subjects triggered a mere half second apart with almost three and a half seconds of overlap It doesn't always vary though sometimes the bright features do agree "on the nose" In order to ascertain overlaps then one needs to look carefully at the small faint details in the random background noise between and Hz Examples In both of the following sets of three bright details O4b Most of the above still applies to the second half of the fourth observing run so far The Hz roll mode transients at Livingston have become much rarer since the filter tuning in late November and are now about as rare as the Hz ones from Hanford We still have the Hz floor motion coupling at Hanford at similar glitch rates to O4a The medium frequency ripples Hz at Hanford have become relatively rare again like they were before mid July but aren't entirely gone in spite of the baffle adjustments between HAM and HAM Hz glitches still show up occasionally There are still presumably beam jitter "pirate ship" glitches at Hanford in all the previously reported bands except near Hz around Hz in particular We've had substantial numbers of violin mode glitches fundamental or 2nd harmonic from both Hanford and Livingston on several occasions almost all of these show nothing visible at all Gone for now is the squeezer's audio band diagnostic field ADF at Hanford tab projects zooniverse https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396198/ OK Much easier to call them flock https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396146/ Aha so if wheatgrass only appears frame what do you call the other stuff at either side of the koifish? Background noise? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Why I call them "fins"! They are part of the Koi Fish glitch They are artefacts of the data processing arising when a loud short duration glitch with much of its noise near Hz interacts with the filtering that removes the ever present Hz noise from the electricity mains supplies Similarly the "lighthouse" effects arise in other subjects when a short duration glitch has enough noise near Hz where the fundamental violin modes ever present to some extent are filtered out Very loud glitches can acquire such artefacts at a number of other frequencies and will then turn into "anglerfish" https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Thank you ZngabitanT https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Blip at with a tomte at which probably has its own object Also diffraction grating https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396657/ Doesn't look like the typical scattered light even with the quiet band between 20Hz The three loud glitches above that band and below 32Hz remind me of a streamlined fish and the single glitch below that band looks like a flattened 'c' https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396667/ non symmetry koi fish https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396682/ maybe 64Hz fuzzy range loud case https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396767/ Atypical koi fish tail off center at also diffraction grating above about 32Hz https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396891/ 128Hz ripple with 'rain' above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396893/ Another Not No Glitch 41Hz Ground motion coupling Also S S S on 2024 https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396948/ Fuzzy? range drops have a brief gap in the plotted curve corresponding to brief drop outs from Observing caused by squeezer unlocks g today LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep and again UTC LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep It is not yet clear what the causal connection is if any Maybe the squeezer subsystem is just another victim of some common environmental influence or maybe it is coupling noise at medium frequencies into the interferometer There are indications LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep that the suspension of the mirror FC at the far end of the squeezer's meter filter cavity has been moving more than it should during some of the times in question in particular in the Hz band Given the laser light circulating back and forth in the filter cavity this could also explain phase noise at multiples of a 62Hz fundamental Yet more of these glitches have arrived overnight Sun Mon As the incoming day shift tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep operator puts it > SQZ dropouts Hz monster is back noisy night LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep with comment refers to a comment on LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep from Friday noting that the noise in DARM and strain is also witnessed by the squeezer's Resonant Locking Field RLF a laser light sideband that circulates in the squeezer's filter cavity alongside the very faint squeezed light field itself before the latter is injected into the interferometer Any motion of the FC mirror suspension would indeed affect both light fields in similar ways Could the Hanford "fuzzy range" episodes have a similar origin? Let's hope it'll succumb to some serious troubleshooting soon even though that'll deprive us of one prolific source of subjects https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3399055/ Hi all! I a scientist working with the Gravity Spy team and the LIGO Detector Characterization group I wanted to reach out to everyone here on Zooniverse to enlist your help in improving the Gravity Spy machine learning based classifications As all of you are aware there have been a few new glitch classes in this past observing run that are quite different from previous observing runs As such the Gravity Spy team is working to update our machine learning models to include these new classes One class of glitch that is particularly confusing the machine learning model is Scattered Light Looking through the set of glitches classified as Scattered Light LIGO researchers have identified at least three different classes that have been placed in this class by the machine learning model These are Traditional scattered light glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional scattering gold set with the arch structure expected of scattered light Cairn glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav cairn gold set like the pile of rocks https en wikipedia org wiki Cairn that are somewhat similar to traditional scattering but without a clear arch structure Hz glitches https www zooniverse org projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set that are a single line of noise near Hz We need a large dataset of each glitch class particularly for Cairn and Hz glitches to help retrain the Gravity Spy model on these classes It would be very helpful if users could be on the lookout for these types of glitches to create larger collections the larger the collection of glitches that we can identify from each class the better the Gravity Spy model will be able to learn the difference between these classes If you notice these glitches or already have a related collection please add a link to your collection in this thread! Do you have any ad blockers installed that could interact with both Chrome and Safari and that might mistakenly prevent them from contacting some of Zooniverse's backend servers while still allowing the main www zooniverse org site to pass? The project Einstein Home Pulsar Seekers projects rsengar einstein at home pulsar seekers is still on the old Zooniverse user interface frontend like Gravity Spy was until about a year ago For an example of another project that's already on the new UI frontend like Gravity Spy is now may I ask you to have a brief look at Black Hole Hunters projects cobalt lensing black hole hunters is that one usable for you or does it show similar symptoms? If that project's Classifier also fails to load properly then we're dealing with some issue between the Zooniverse infrastructure and your setup and not with something specific to Gravity Spy In this case I would recomment to start a new thread in the Zooniverse > Talk > Troubleshooting tab talk board following the instructions in the thread pinned at the top there tab talk If Black Hole Hunters works for you while Gravity Spy does not then further browser side debugging may be required to isolate which step exactly is failing Have you used g Safari's Web Inspector tool before? It could be used to look at the dozens of browser server interactions during each single page load in detail and compare at which point the sequence begins to differ between the two projects Good luck and do let me know how it goes! LVK sensitivity curves https gwosc org summary pages detector status cache day G1H1L1V OBSERVING HOFT SPECTRUM png tab https gwosc org detector status day And at the frequencies corresponding to the "yardarms" there'll be vertical spikes sticking out These are what the engineers mean when they talk about spectral lines in the measured gravitational strain data stream Normally they're filtered out completely before our subject images are produced So we don't get to see them in our subjects unless there's either a loud glitch upsetting the filtering or unless something has made them fluctuate in intensity on a timescale shorter than about seconds https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3375093/ Thank you Is there any particular classification other than extremely loud? to be aware of when checking for overlaps At the high levels of background noise that existed during the middle of the episode both the energy normalization and the whitening which suppresses stationary noise can vary substantially from one subject to the next resulting in quite noticeable visual differences in the bright yellow artefacts the "fins" of the baby Koi Fish in the lower halves of the images even for subjects triggered a mere half second apart with almost three and a half seconds of overlap It doesn't always vary though sometimes the bright features do agree "on the nose" In order to ascertain overlaps then one needs to look carefully at the small faint details in the random background noise between and Hz Examples In both of the following sets of three bright details O4b Most of the above still applies to the second half of the fourth observing run so far The Hz roll mode transients at Livingston have become much rarer since the filter tuning in late November and are now about as rare as the Hz ones from Hanford We still have the Hz floor motion coupling at Hanford at similar glitch rates to O4a The medium frequency ripples Hz at Hanford have become relatively rare again like they were before mid July but aren't entirely gone in spite of the baffle adjustments between HAM and HAM Hz glitches still show up occasionally There are still presumably beam jitter "pirate ship" glitches at Hanford in all the previously reported bands except near Hz around Hz in particular We've had substantial numbers of violin mode glitches fundamental or 2nd harmonic from both Hanford and Livingston on several occasions almost all of these show nothing visible at all Gone for now is the squeezer's audio band diagnostic field ADF at Hanford tab projects zooniverse https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396198/ OK Much easier to call them flock https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396146/ Aha so if wheatgrass only appears frame what do you call the other stuff at either side of the koifish? Background noise? https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Why I call them "fins"! They are part of the Koi Fish glitch They are artefacts of the data processing arising when a loud short duration glitch with much of its noise near Hz interacts with the filtering that removes the ever present Hz noise from the electricity mains supplies Similarly the "lighthouse" effects arise in other subjects when a short duration glitch has enough noise near Hz where the fundamental violin modes ever present to some extent are filtered out Very loud glitches can acquire such artefacts at a number of other frequencies and will then turn into "anglerfish" https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Thank you ZngabitanT https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396170/ Blip at with a tomte at which probably has its own object Also diffraction grating https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396657/ Doesn't look like the typical scattered light even with the quiet band between 20Hz The three loud glitches above that band and below 32Hz remind me of a streamlined fish and the single glitch below that band looks like a flattened 'c' https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396667/ non symmetry koi fish https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396682/ maybe 64Hz fuzzy range loud case https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396767/ Atypical koi fish tail off center at also diffraction grating above about 32Hz https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396891/ 128Hz ripple with 'rain' above https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396893/ Another Not No Glitch 41Hz Ground motion coupling Also S S S on 2024 https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3396948/ Fuzzy? range drops have a brief gap in the plotted curve corresponding to brief drop outs from Observing caused by squeezer unlocks g today LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep and again UTC LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep It is not yet clear what the causal connection is if any Maybe the squeezer subsystem is just another victim of some common environmental influence or maybe it is coupling noise at medium frequencies into the interferometer There are indications LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep that the suspension of the mirror FC at the far end of the squeezer's meter filter cavity has been moving more than it should during some of the times in question in particular in the Hz band Given the laser light circulating back and forth in the filter cavity this could also explain phase noise at multiples of a 62Hz fundamental Yet more of these glitches have arrived overnight Sun Mon As the incoming day shift tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep operator puts it > SQZ dropouts Hz monster is back noisy night LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep with comment refers to a comment on LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep from Friday noting that the noise in DARM and strain is also witnessed by the squeezer's Resonant Locking Field RLF a laser light sideband that circulates in the squeezer's filter cavity alongside the very faint squeezed light field itself before the latter is injected into the interferometer Any motion of the FC mirror suspension would indeed affect both light fields in similar ways Could the Hanford "fuzzy range" episodes have a similar origin?
