few question from you and Coralbell I agree that there's quite a wide range of different morphologies that could be fit into the scattered light model We haven't noticed as many issues with the Hz scattering being misclassified so that subclass is not as high of a concern for the machine learning classifications at present We are interested in glitches from all of O if they are present The collections I linked are only some of the most recent glitches that researchers had identified as problematic for the machine learning classifications We are also interested in H glitches if present Some further questions and remarks So I gather the point is to teach the ML about glitches that it should not label as Scattered Light but currently does while also making sure that it will still recognize subjects that are instances of "traditional" Scattered Light Will you be able to train the ML on collections of "mere" counterexamples penalizing it for misclassifications without assigning a specific other "good" class to each "this isn't Scattered Light" subject? I understand that this hasn't been possible in the past If this still isn't possible then we need to be more careful about the training sets we're going to build They should not just collect other than Scattered Light subjects but each of them should collect subjects that really belong together into a different class They should focus on core rather than fringe examples of these different classes And they should capture the essence of each of these other classes In particular they shouldn't be limited to subjects rendered at Q only when the other class under consideration has been attracting renderings at other Q values in signficant numbers I'm hopeful that Cairn will turn out to be a good if not very populous class grouping glitches together that share a common origin As far as I can see so far it will have to include examples rendered at lower Q values and it is mostly a Livingston thing "Similar" looking subjects from Hanford are numerous but are invariably something else most Scattered Light from Hanford O4a tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk 3013446?comment O4b looks somewhat cairn ish except for the Q "wheatgrass" renderings On the other hand I'm sceptical about the Hz subjects The three initial gold examples tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav hz gold set may turn out to be three different things spanning a range of peak frequencies as reported by Omicron and one of them visibly sloping I don't think they are tied to any specific fixed frequency features spectral lines Livingston has had a few ! glitches specifically at Hz about a year ago see LLO tab https alog ligo la caltech edu aLOG index php?callRep tab is one of these that has got labeled Scattered Light with not very high confidence but others like tab got more plausibly filed under Low Frequency Lines I'm not aware of any more recent fixed frequency glitch sources at Livingston in the Hz ballpark From Hanford we have firstly the medium frequency ripples and combs tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk showing up around and and and Hz the ones peaking near Hz have occasionally received Scattered Light labels g tab but more often Low Frequency Lines tab or No Glitch tab and secondly the Hz floor motion coupling tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk These glitches could last up to several minutes at a time and often got whitened out so thoroughly that the image producing part of Gravity Spy picked a Q value at random and left us and the ML with nothing to see These subjects are still recognizable by their peak frequencies and durations but hopeless to classify purely by the resulting images tab is a rare example rendered at Q that has attracted a Scattered Light label Here too Low Frequency Lines and No Glitch occur more often Both of these glitch class proposals already link to relevant collections But the many "NotNoGlitch" examples won't do much good in training a purely image based ML They would require a more sophisticated ML which also pays attention to the Omicron metadata peak frequency duration and SNR and perhaps one which receives renderings at all four Q values as its image input not just at a single choice which may or may not match the given glitch very well I can't help noticing that all the current members of the Traditional Scattering Gold Set tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav traditional scattering gold set with one possible exception are marginal cases of Livingston's Hz scattering tab projects zooniverse gravity spy talk marginal in the sense that the ground was moving at somewhat less than Hz and the penduluming item excited below its resonance was able to follow the ground motion so the arches we see are spaced more than seconds apart and all of them are Q renderings The glitch subclass proposal already links to a more representative candidate training set tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections zngabitant training set l a dot hz scattering from O4a These glitches have not changed much between O4a and O4b But apropos of this another question springs to mind Many of these Hz scattering glitches stay below the Hz band of loud stationary noise and thus do less harm to clean observing time than those which do show up loudly above Hz As long as we're aiming to classify by common causes and common coupling paths they all belong together Nevertheless would it make sense to maintain a distinction between very low frequency Scattered Light peak frequency below Hz and the more harmful sort peak above Hz ? As to the definition of Cairns the provided golden set tab projects zooniverse gravity spy collections dethodav cairn gold set includes examples where the bright parts reach up to about Hz the lower cutoff at about Hz is determined by the upper edge of the loud but whitened away from sight stationary noise band and the visible durations usually exceed seconds and can reach about seconds The durations reported by Omicron can be even longer sometimes exceeding seconds In this regard I guess we should do as dethodav does not as dethodav says Now having looked at many subjects in the past and having used the glitch plotter on O and earlier subjects imagine what a lower Q rendering would do to such a glitch It is impossible to predict the precise shape the Q transform is a projection it loses information but we can foretell that there'll be somewhat less stretching of the overall shape in the horizontal direction and somewhat more in the vertical direction so the visible durations will tend to be a bit shorter while the vertical extent may then stick out a bit beyond the Hz range the more so the lower the Q value is chosen I haven't yet found convincing examples at Q or but I'm keeping my eyes open I've recently had to deal with all those "fuzzy range" subjects which can get rendered at any old Q so my brain is currently flooded with illustrations of how the rendering choice affects the appearance of an underlying population that's intrinsically uniform with some variability One reason why I said up front that lower Q examples of Cairns must exist is that I had already run into several candidates a few weeks ago including and as by catch during similarity searches based on other kinds of subjects I didn't immediately know what to do with them and didn't yet have a name for them and moreover I was very busy with other things that needed urgent attention Thus for a while these candidates were left sitting in very different corners of my queues not wanting to neatly fit anywhere I'm now digging through all these odd corners and trying to re unite the puzzle pieces that now suddenly seem to belong together It's certainly true that lower Q renderings of     Below are a list of interests I would like an answer for. Please provide at least three bullet points, each with a couple of sentences responding to each interest.     I want a list of novel things which occur in Talk Dataset 2 realtive to Talk Dataset 1.
    1. Citizen scientists are actively identifying and categorizing new types of glitches based on their unique characteristics. I want to know what new glitch classes are proposed. If Talk data set 2 proposes a new glitch class realtive to Talk data set 1, what is the glitch class? How do they describe this glitch class? Provide at least a bullet point for each proposed new glitch class with at least two sentences describing it.

    2. Citizen scientists sometimes question whether there are problems with existing glitch classes: i.e. those listed. I am interested in whether there are any concerns regarding the glitch classes according to the citizen scientists, and whether or not they persist in both sets of Talk Datasets, or if concerns occur only in Talk Dataset 2. If there are concerns, what problems are they claiming exist with the classifcations? Provide at least a couple of sentences describing each concern raised.

    3. Additionally, citizen scientists wish to deepen their knowledge by exploring and learning classifications and technical aspects of glitches. I am interested in whether there are emerging questions related to the glitch classes, sensors, or gravitational wave science in Talk data set 2 relative to Talk data set 1. Describe each question and the reasoning for the question. Provide at least three sentences describing these emerging questions.

    4. The origins of glitches are usually related to enviornemntal factors near the sensors or errors in measurements of sensors themselves. Citizen scientists often attempt to analytically correlate external conditions with glitch occurrences, providing specific hypothetical origins of glitches suggesting potentially gained knowledge in underlying mechanisms of glitch causes or their appearances in spectograms. If Talk data set 2 has more specific hypotheses about where glitch origins, what are these hypotheses? What is each hypothesis' analytical motivation? Provide at least three sentences describing each hypothesis.

    5. Often citizen scientists will question if issues are specifically related to particular sensors or channels. Are there any emerging questions or thoughts concerning the way particular glitches are connected to sensors or channels in Talk Dataset 2 relative to Talk Dataset 1? If these thoughts or questions exist, what specifically do they describe? Provide at least two sentences for these questions or thoughts.

ChatCompletion(id='chatcmpl-9rRSawWQekcQEdU2SjK3nUqysnRVP', choices=[Choice(finish_reason='stop', index=0, logprobs=None, message=ChatCompletionMessage(content='### Novel Glitch Classes in Talk Dataset 2\n\n1. **Fuzzy Range Glitches**: In Talk Dataset 2, a new glitch class referred to as "Fuzzy Range" is highlighted by citizen scientists. These glitches are described by their occurrence predominantly at certain frequencies and are marked by a less defined, "fuzzy" appearance on the spectograms. They are speculated to be associated with environmental or instrumental influences causing broad frequency spectrum disturbances.\n   - URL: [Fuzzy Range Discussion](https://www.zooniverse.org/projects/zooniverse/gravity-spy/talk/328/3401049/)\n\n2. **Cairn Glitches**: This newly identified glitch class is named "Cairn." Described as resembling pyramid-shaped configurations in the spectral plots, these glitches seem to be distinct in their manifestation.
